generic: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B, and Polio Vaccine
drugs: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B, and Polio Vaccine

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B, and Polio Vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hepatitis B vaccination: (6 weeks to younger than 7 years) starting at 2 months, 0.5 mL IM at 6- to 8-week intervals for 3 doses (8-week intervals preferred); can be started as early as 6 weeks of age
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hepatitis B vaccination: (6 weeks to younger than 7 years) can be given for series completion in those who received 1 or 2 doses of hepatitis B vaccine (Recombinant) or 1 or 2 doses of Infanrix(R) or IPV, and are scheduled to receive the other vaccine components of Pediarix(R); not indicated as the fourth dose of IPV or the fourth and fifth dose of DTaP
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hepatitis B vaccination: (6 weeks to younger than 7 years) 3 doses can be administered to infants born to a hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-positive woman or whose HBsAg status is unknown; it is acceptable to administer DTaP-HepB-IPV (Pediarix(R)) following the birth dose of single antigen HepB vaccine resulting in a 4-dose HepB series (guideline dosing)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hepatitis B vaccination

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• allergic reaction, severe (eg, anaphylaxis), after a previous dose of any diphtheria toxoid-, tetanus toxoid-, pertussis antigen-, hepatitis B-, or poliovirus-containing vaccine, or to any vaccine component, including yeast, neomycin, and polymyxin B
  • encephalopathy (eg, coma, decreased level of consciousness, prolonged seizures) within 7 days of administration of a previous pertussis-containing vaccine that is not attributable to another identifiable cause
  • progressive neurologic disorder (eg, infantile spasms, uncontrolled epilepsy, or progressive encephalopathy); defer vaccination until neurologic status is clarified and stabilized

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • children at high risk for seizures; an antipyretic medication, given at the time of vaccination and for 24 hours post-vaccination, may reduce risk of fever
  • collapse or shock-like state (hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode) within 48 hours of receipt of pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • fever of 40.5 degrees C (105 degrees F) or greater within 48 hours of receipt of pertussis-containing vaccine, not due to another identifiable cause; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome within 6 weeks of previous tetanus toxoid-containing vaccination
  • hypersensitivity reaction, arthus-type, after a previous tetanus-toxoid-containing vaccine; defer vaccination until at least 10 years since last tetanus-toxoid-containing vaccine
  • latex sensitivity; tip cap of the prefilled syringes may contain natural latex rubber
  • persistent, inconsolable crying lasting for 3 hours or more, occurring within 48 hours of receipt of pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • pregnancy; can be administered if there is a risk for exposure to wild-type poliovirus infection
  • premature infants; apnea has been observed following intramuscular vaccination; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • revaccination in patients with unknown vaccination history; after the fourth and fifth DTaP dose an increased rate of adverse events may occur; serologic testing may be indicated
  • seizures with or without fever occurring within 3 days of receipt of pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • syncope, possibly accompanied by transient neurological signs (eg, visual disturbance, paresthesia, tonic-clonic limb movements), may occur
  • report suspected adverse effects to the Vaccine Adverse Events Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (24.9% to 40.1%), Injection site edema (17.3% to 28.7%), Injection site pain (31.2% to 36.1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Loss of appetite (26.2% to 30.6%)
  • Neurologic:Somnolence (40.9% to 57.2%)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (60.5% to 64.9%)
  • Other:Fever (27.9% to 38.8%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cyanosis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Encephalitis, Seizure, Febrile and afebrile (0.07 to 0.14 per 1000 doses)
  • Psychiatric:Crying, excessive
  • Respiratory:Bronchiolitis
  • Other:Angioedema, Death, Sudden infant death syndrome

sub.title: Synonyms
sub.mono:
• DTaP, Hepatitis B, and Polio Vaccine
  • Diphtheria, Tetanus Toxoid, Acellular Pertussis Absorbed, Hepatitis B (Recombinant), and Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine
  • DTaP-HepB-IPV - Diphtheria and Tetanus Toxoids and Acellular Pertussis Adsorbed, Hepatitis B and Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Systemic: Diphtheria: Following intramuscular injection, diphtheria toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to diphtheria toxin.
  • Tetanus: Following intramuscular injection, tetanus toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to tetanus toxin.
  • Pertussis: Following intramuscular injection, acellular pertussis vaccine induces the formation of several antibodies thought to be clinically protective. The levels of antibody necessary for protection have not been determined.
  • Hepatitis B: Following intramuscular injection, antibody formation against HBsAg are recognized.
  • Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine: Following intramuscular injection, IPV induces the production of neutralizing antibodies against each poliovirus serotype.
  • According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC), hepatitis B vaccine is recognized as the first anti-cancer vaccine because it can prevent primary liver cancer. A clear link has been demonstrated between chronic hepatitis B infection and the occurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    • IM only; do not administer SUBQ, IV, or intradermally
    • may be administered concomitantly with Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate and pneumococcal vaccines in separate syringes and at separate injection sites
  • Intramuscular
    • shake prefilled syringe well before use; do not use if resuspension does not occur with vigorous shaking
    • attach a sterile needle to syringe for IM injection
    • administer concurrent injectable vaccines using separate syringe and at different injection site; do not mix with any other vaccine in same syringe
    • administer in the anterolateral aspects of the thigh in children younger than 1 year or in the deltoid muscle in older children; do not inject in the gluteal area or areas where there may be a major nerve trunk; gluteal injections may result in suboptimal hepatitis B immune response

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause an injection site reaction or fever.
  • Inform caregiver of the importance of the child receiving the entire series of vaccinations. If a dose is missed, another appointment should be scheduled as soon as possible.
